title: Roman urbanism in the ancient world (2023-2024)
description:
####Learning objectives

The expansion of Rome led to a particular form of social organisation: the Roman city. In the continuity of the Mediterranean city-states, this territorial modality of the civitas gave rise to several urban centres surrounded by their own territories, whose juxtaposition durably structured the Roman Empire. Organised around a community of citizens who governed it, the populus, the city enjoyed a certain autonomy under the same law. Buildings and monuments were the embodiment of this community and represented urbanitas, the urban way of life.

The objective of the course is to set out the modalities and the timeline of this expansion as well as the acceptance of the Roman Urban in the North West of the Roman Empire as any very first urbanisation in Europe.

####Details of the learning scenario

Workload: 72h - The student's work will consist of following the weekly exercises without notation.

Final assessment: The evaluation is a final exam, a written test on the questions developed in the practice exercises.

#### Schedule/Timetable of the learning offer

Starts: **26/02/2024**

Ends: **24/05/2024**

title: Luxury: social psychological approaches for professionals  (2023-2024)
description:
####Learning objectives

The main objective of the course Luxury: social psychological approaches for professionals is to make students familiar with a social psychological perspective on the interactions in the world of luxury.
 
The course addresses the social psychological interactions and processes that underlie the world of luxury, as well as professional contexts in luxury businesses such as hotels, resorts, restaurants, the fashion world, make-up universes, etc. 

First, the course provides students with the social psychological keys to understand and contextualise the ways in which people think, feel, and behave in relation to luxury. 
 
Secondly, the course considers the contemporary stakes in the luxury world - for example, environmental concerns, as well as interactional stakes between luxury professionals and clients. 
 
Thirdly, the course equips students with the knowledge and tools to better understand the functioning of small groups, which are often created in luxury businesses: group affiliation and membership in work teams, leadership and its relation to group performance and group climate, norm formation, conformity, obedience, social influence, and social change, etc.
 
In addition, the course contributes to the development of students’ soft skills, such as active listening, leadership, conflict management, group work, cross-cultural interactional skills.

####Details of the learning scenario

A quiz is to complete for each topic.

Workload: 54 hours 

Final Assessment: Case study : a social psychological analysis (options : luxury fashion, luxury make-up, or luxury tourism)

#### Schedule/Timetable of the learning offer

Starts: **04/03/2024**

Ends: **13/05/2024**

title: The Fall of an Empire or the Rise of Europe? (Spring 2024)
description:
#### Learning objectives

In the traditional historiographical narrative, the arrival of the “barbarians” corresponds to the end of the greatest civilization of the antique Mediterranean: the Roman Empire. But was the situation so simple? Who were these “barbarians”? And did the Empire really collapse or was it rather transformed? The goal of this course is to focus on the artistic, visual, material, and performative cultures that coexisted in this extraordinary moment of history. To reach this objective, we will firstly focus on the prejudices constructed from the Renaissance to our days about what was commonly considered as the “Dark Ages”. Secondly, we will be investigating the role of medias in the transformations of visual history: from sculptures to “bidimensional” images, from roll to codex, from the illusive image to the iconic one. Third, we will analyze the role played by the meeting of cultures – constitutive for the investigated period – in the birth of the “Middle Ages”.

This course is taught by the Department of Art History at Masaryk University. 

At the end of the course participants will:
- be able to orientate himself in the visual and material cultures of the Late Antique to Early Medieval world;
- understand the tools and the importance of visual culture within social and historical phenomena;
- fall in love with art history!

#### Details of the learning scenario

This learning offer is **asynchronous**, which means that this is an e-learning course (e-learning materials + final essay).

Please consider a workload per the whole course of 125 hours (25 hours/1 ECTS).
prerequisites: If you are MU student, please register course ARTS006 in IS (Faculty of Arts), your ECTS will be recognised faster.

description:
#### Learning objectives
**NOTE: Language of this offer is SPANISH**

Language cafés are not structured language courses. Instead, they are an opportunity for an informal online exchange between students from different linguistic and cultural backgrounds. Hence, we ask that participants’ language level be at least a B2. 
Students who are passionate about languages have the opportunity to participate in this activity in their free time to chat about all things related to languages and cultures in a relaxed and casual environment. Tutors of native-speaker level will be there to co-ordinate the sessions. Participants are encouraged to actively contribute to the sessions and have their say in planning future topics and activities.

Café sessions last approximately one hour and take place regularly online during the University of Potsdam's lecture period (please see schedule details below). Please note that no ECTS points can be awarded for participating in the language café sessions. Students can join the language café via the Open.UP platform at any time during the semester. There is no application deadline. However, please note that slots for the language café sessions are subject to availability, as the number of places is limited.
The link to Open.UP, where EDUC students can register for the language café and set up their own account, can be found below. In addition, a Zoom account is required to participate online.


#### Schedule/Timetable of the learning offer

End: 19/07/2024

**From 08.04.2024 the schedule for the weekly appointments will be set on Open.UP. Stay tuned!**

title: German A1 at Zessko (Spring 2024): Weekly Video Meetings (Zoom) + Moodle-based learning
description:
#### Learning objectives

The course is aimed at learners who would like to begin studying German or go further after having taken a very few initial steps, – be it informal out-of-classroom learning, more formal in an A1.1 course, or self-directed online learning with Zessko’s “German A1 Starter” (https://courses.educalliance.eu/course/165) on the EDUC Moodle. 
Built on an action-orientated approach and a fully Moodle-based online learning material, the course addresses reception, production, interaction and mediation in terms of language activities in connection with language strategies in various but typical areas of communication related to academic life in Potsdam. Consequently, it does neither claim to “cover” the whole level A1 according to the CEFR nor to provide A1 exam training. Instead, it is to empower successful participants to take their first steps in a German speaking surrounding and – equally important – to manage their further language acquisition.

Upon successfully engaging in this course, learners:
- can recognise concrete information (e.g., places and times) on familiar topics encountered in everyday life, provided it is delivered slowly and clearly.
- can understand some expressions when people are discussing them: personal and academic life, hobbies or surroundings, provided the delivery is slow and clear.
- can understand instructions addressed carefully and slowly to them and follow short, simple directions.
- can understand very short, simple texts a single phrase at a time, picking up familiar names, words and basic phrases.
- can guess the probable meaning of an unknown word/sign that is similar to one in the language they normally use.
- can produce simple, mainly isolated phrases about people, time and places.
- can ask and answer simple questions, initiate and respond to simple statements in areas of immediate need or on very familiar topics.
- can make an introduction and use basic greeting and leave-taking expressions.
- can ask for food and drink using basic expressions.
- can handle numbers, quantities, cost and time (can-do statements according to the CEFR).

#### Details of the learning scenario

Mode: Regular video meetings via Zoom (language learning discussions, collaborative task-based learning) connected with asynchronous individual learning through Moodle (learning videos, exercises and quizzes, assignments).

**Workload: 180 h (*equivalent to 6 ECTS)**

#### Schedule/Timetable of the learning offer

Starting: 08/04/2024
End: 19/07/2024

Exam: most likely mid-July 2024

Weekly video meetings (Zoom):
**presumably Thursdays: weekly, 16:00 - 19:30 h (to be confirmed)**

### Certificate
Certificate of attendance, Zessko's A1 certificate upon passing the A1 exam, digital documents will be made available via Moodle.
prerequisites:
Enrolment at any of the EDUC universities

Please do only apply if 
- you can virtually attend the video meetings on Thursdays from 4pm to 7:30 pm – you need to have access to a computer with a rather large screen, a camera and a microphone (good quality headset preferred) as well as a fast and steady internet connection – and
- you can spend at least 8 hours per week on the individual learning (see “Details of the learning scenario”).

title: Memorable Speaking: Making an Impact (English Oral Proficiency II) - Spring 2024
description:
#### Learning objectives

What makes a speech memorable? In this collaborative online international learning (COIL) project between the University of Potsdam and Beit Berl College (Israel), students listen to and learn from noted speakers in the fields of business, politics, literature, and education. In turn, students share their ideas on these topics by making memorable speeches of their own. We welcome students from the EDUC alliance to participate in some of the sessions (**for no ECTS points**) or for all of the sessions (for an EDUC certificate certifying the workload).
Please see "More Info" for the course time, expected outcomes, and requirements.

In this course students should master oral communication of an informative, explanatory, and persuasive nature through presenting. Upon successful completion of this course, students should be able

- to understand and identify the principles of various presentation formats
- to structure and present academic and professional presentations effectively
- to develop a central argument and to support it with compelling subpoints
- to formulate coherent ideas and opinions and express them precisely and succinctly
- to use appropriate transitions and signposting language to help the audience navigate a presentation
- to integrate and correctly reference credible sources as evidence for their argumentation
- to strengthen their verbal delivery using appropriate pronunciation features (e.g., chunking, emphatic stress, etc.)
  and non-verbal language for advanced communicative competence
- to feel confident in posing and responding to questions during a presentation

Students are required to participate in weekly class discussions. Independent study is an integral component of the course. Students are strongly encouraged to attend the English Language Café. (Your instructor will provide you with information; see also the departmental website.)

This learning offer is **synchronous**

title: Writing Across Cultures (English Academic Writing II) - Spring 2024
description:
#### Learning objectives

Taking the UNESCO working paper "Intercultural Competence: Conceptual and Operational Framework" (Leeds-Hurwitzand Stenou, 2013) as a springboard, we investigate the meaning and relevance of intercultural competence in today's world. Students then research and write about a topic of their choosing that is related to intercultural competence. Exercises that develop students' peer review skills will help them to identify and correct errors in their peers' and in their own writing. We view writing squarely as a process and consequently do portfolio work over the course of the semester. The semester culminates in a short presentation of the students' essays.
We welcome students in the EDUC alliance to participate in some of the sessions (**for no ECTS points**) or for all of the sessions (for an EDUC certificate certifying the workload). Passive participants will be removed from the Moodle course.

This two-hour writing course centers on essay writing and the argumentative essay in particular. Upon completion of this course, students will be able
- to express themselves using nuanced language (improved accuracy and appropriacy of writing)
- to produce cohesive and coherent academic writing (improved complexity and effectiveness of writing)
- to identify and produce various types of academic texts
- to evaluate their own and others' texts (peer review)
- to assess and cite (MLA) appropriate sources properly

#### Details of the learning scenario

This learning offer is **synchronous**

title: Online Language Assessment Preparation and Practice (English) 2024
description:
These asynchronous courses are designed for EDUC students utilizing self-guided activities to prepare them for language exams in English, German, Hungarian and Czech – four of the languages represented in the EDUC network of universities. Students enrolling in the course will have opportunities to practice developing their receptive (reading and listen) and productive (writing and speaking) skills in these four languages, working through typical tasks found on language exams. These courses are built around the European Consortium of Languages (ECL), which is the University of Pecs’ foreign language exam system offering ECUC students and others across the EU and aboard language exam certificates in more than ten languages.

This online language assessment preparation course in Moodle will be structured around six learning modules for the target language and CEFR level: 1.) Introduction to the ECL Language Examination System at the University of Pecs, 2.) Reading section of assessment, 3.) Writing section of assessment, 4.) Listening section of assessment, 5.) Speaking section of assessment, and 6.) Online Practice Exam. In Moodle, participants will work through a series of pre-recorded screen casts of Google Slides and Prezi presentations to learn more about the content they can expect to encounter on the ECL language exam. They will also have access to PDF files, sample language assessments, and additional online resources to assist in preparation. All modules will include asynchronous resources for EDUC staff and students to work through the productive and receptive skills independently and at their own pace. However, the modules will include the following recommend time (Total Time: 6 weeks/22 hours) to spend on each language learning task in order to successfully prepare for a language assessment in the selected EDUC language. 

Teacher: Peter Sabath (UPE/PTE) https://inyk.pte.hu/munkatarsaink/

title: Refugee Integration? Critical reflections on history and the present 2024
description:
Section 1: Learning objectives

This intensive blended course delves into the global history of processes of refuge-seeking: it explores the many challenges that refugees and migrants face and the opportunities they create in receiving countries. It engages the manifold ways in which citizens have responded to migrants and refugees over time – from the Huguenots’ arrival in Brandenburg-Prussia in 1685 to the present – and in various places, including France, Australia, Uganda, Ethiopia, and Germany. The course also examines the responses and visions of migrants and refugees themselves.

The course brings together 30 students from six European universities through the European Digital UniverCity alliance (EDUC), for ten weeks of online learning (starting on April 17, 2022) followed by a week together in Potsdam June 24-29, 2024. In Potsdam students will meet with local decision-makers, civil society and church representatives, and migrants and refugees to learn first-hand about practices and issues relating to migration and integration.

To prepare for this, students will be introduced to theories around integration and will then engage with historic and contemporary case studies that highlight particular issues such as culture, religion, racism, education, and labour in relation to assimilationism and multiculturalism.

Overall, the aim of this course is to provide students with the theoretical and conceptual language to make sense of historical processes of refuge-seeking and integration as well as enabling a lively exchange between student perspectives and practitioners’ insights on processes of integration in the city of Potsdam.

At the end of the course participants will:
- develop an understanding of integration / multiculturalism / assimilation
- develop an understanding of historic roots of present-day integration challenges
- realize the global scale of integration measures
- reflect on interconnections between refugee and migration integration
- develop critical reading and reflection skills
-develop analysis of primary and secondary sources skills
- develop teamwork skills
-develop oral and written presentation skills
- develop intercultural skills
-develop transfer skills from historic case studies to present circumstances

Section 2: Details of the learning scenario

This learning offer is a “blended” one, which means that it is divided in two phases: an Online Program from April 19th to June 14th, 2022 consisting of one lesson every Tuesday from 16:00 to 18:00 h. And an On-site program from 24th to 29th of June, 2024.
Location: Online | University of Potsdam, Campus Neues Palais. 

Please consider a work-load:
- Online: 8 hours per week
- Onsite: 40 hours per week

The minimum technical requirements you need to participate are: a 5 Mbps Internet connexion and a Zoom account
